vmassol joined #xwiki at 14:26  
sburjan - (14:38): cjdelisle, abusenius jvdrean : ping  
abusenius - (14:38): pong  
sburjan - (14:39): abusenius, : I want to use maven to create a jar containing the sources for a project test classes  
sburjan - (14:40): from console  
abusenius - (14:41): sources=java?  
sburjan - (14:41): yes  
sburjan - (14:41): something like ui-tests-src.jar  
sburjan - (14:41): i'd like to create a jar with all the sources  
sburjan - (14:41): basically  
sburjan - (14:42): but in this particular example, ui-tests has code only in src/tests  
sburjan - (14:42): tried several commands, but none of the actually create anything, even if build is succesfull  
abusenius - (14:42): take a look at ui-test/pom.xml  
abusenius - (14:42): search for jar  
sburjan - (14:42): so I can't create without altering the pom ?  
abusenius - (14:43): I haven't tried it  
abusenius - (14:43): you'd need to provide the configuration for the jar plugin on command line  
jvelociter - (14:43): sburjan: try "maven javadoc:javadoc"  
jvelociter - (14:44): http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-javadoc-plugin/  
abusenius - (14:47): if you just need the sources inside and nothing else, I'd simply zip them  
sburjan - (14:51): yeah, I'm just trying some maven stuff  
sburjan - (15:03): build succesfull  
sburjan - (15:03): yet no artefact  
vmassol left at 15:20 (Quit: Leaving.  
bblfish joined #xwiki at 15:36  
bblfish - (15:37): what's the latest stable mvn version for xwiki-applications ?  
bblfish - (15:37): currently I am using 30-SNAPSHOT  
bblfish - (15:44): well I suppose it's this http://maven.xwiki.org/releases/org/xwiki/platform/applications/xwiki-applications/30/  
asrfel left at 16:02 (Quit: Leaving.  
cjdelisle - (16:05): bblfish: http://svn.xwiki.org/svnroot/xwiki/platform/core/trunk/xwiki-crypto/src/main/java/org/xwiki/crypto/x509/X509CryptoService.java  
cjdelisle - (16:05): specifically certsFromSpkac(  
bblfish - (16:06): ok. I am going to make a maven central distribution of the core code for keygen that will be used by Clerezza too  
bblfish - (16:07): then you can take the pieces I have for xwiki and add it to your repo if you want  
bblfish - (16:08): mind you it looks like you have already integrated a lot of this  
cjdelisle - (16:08): Pretty much all except the IE support. I don't have windows so I couldn't do any testing.  
bblfish - (16:09): well I'll point you to the library. Sometime it can help to have common shared code...  
cjdelisle - (16:09): And I don't have the end which does https with client cert.  
bblfish - (16:10): ah mind you your code is LGPL whereas the code we are publishing is BSD  
cjdelisle - (16:10): Does foafssl have a version number in the cert?  
bblfish - (16:10): the version I am distributing has a specific DN. But that has not been formally decided yet  
sburjan left at 16:11 (Ping timeout: 258 seconds  
cjdelisle - (16:11): K so the only part that matters is the webid extension?  
bblfish - (16:11): yes the SAN  
bblfish - (16:11): though it may help further down to have an agreed on CN  
bblfish - (16:11): or perhaps just a OU  
cjdelisle - (16:12): Ok, then our stuff is compatible.  
bblfish - (16:12): yes, nobody is checking that  
cjdelisle - (16:12): Can I recommend adding a number like 0.1 somewhere?  
bblfish - (16:12): now if you want to see a very interesting implementation of foaf+ssl in Scala that was placed directly in the ssl layer...  
bblfish - (16:13): I think the only place to put that is somwhere in the DN  
cjdelisle - (16:13): I have a touch time reading non java/c/perl languages.  
bblfish - (16:13): no need to read it really, the interesting thing is that it can be done.  
cjdelisle - (16:13): right now our dn has only the user name in the form xwiki:XWiki.JohnSmith  
bblfish - (16:14): the CAs DN?  
bblfish - (16:14): yes  
bblfish - (16:14): or the subject DN  
cjdelisle - (16:14): No the user cert dn. The reason is because I wanted to make the signatures as small as possible.  
bblfish - (16:14): that is premature optimisiation  
bblfish - (16:15): the CN of the user should be a human readable string  
bblfish - (16:15): it's what most browsers present to the user  
bblfish - (16:15): so I have "bblfish (xwiki)" "bblifhs (home)" to save me having to look at the SAN  
cjdelisle - (16:15): We will have signatures in the code if a wiki page so short is important.  
bblfish - (16:15): ?  
cjdelisle - (16:16): I have made it able to use crypto.signText in the mozilla browser.  
bblfish - (16:16): http://esw.w3.org/Foaf%2Bssl/Clients/CertSelection  
bblfish - (16:17): that shows how the CN is uses in most UIs  
cjdelisle - (16:18): which part of the cn is that? the UID?  
bblfish - (16:18): no the CN=  
bblfish - (16:18): in the DN  
bblfish - (16:18): the DN is the whole thing  
bblfish - (16:18): the CN is the Common Name  
cjdelisle - (16:18): ahh yes.  
bblfish - (16:18): you should ask the user to set that  
cjdelisle - (16:19): Maybe I'll add it back in.   IMO it should be set for the user, it's tough enough for a user to make a key without having to name it.  
bblfish - (16:19): but if you think there should be a version number, that is something to ask on the mailing list - because everyone would have to agree  
bblfish - (16:20): if you set it for the user, and he ends up having a few, then he's going to be very confused when he selects one  
bblfish - (16:20): you should just ask him for a mnemonic  
bblfish - (16:20): and if he does not set  one, create one  
cjdelisle - (16:21): maybe something like "John Smith (www.mycoolwiki.com)  
cjdelisle - (16:21): "  
vmassol joined #xwiki at 16:21  
cjdelisle - (16:22): re the version number, the reason is because we might figure out faster ways to load a cert from a website.  
cjdelisle - (16:25): so if the cert says the version number it was created with and the site which the user is authenticating with hits the site holding the cert with a header specifying the highest version number it can handle, then maybe in future versions the site only responds with the cert and nothing else?  
cjdelisle - (16:25): maybe the request is made with a single udp packet?  
cjdelisle - (16:25): who knows what the future will bring.  
bblfish - (16:27): yes, it is in fact possible to request only certs from a server signed by a specific CA  
bblfish - (16:27): and so we could have a specific CA for v1, then one for v2 etc  
bblfish - (16:27): but it's also a bit tricky for other reasons...  
bblfish - (16:27): something we need to discuss  
cjdelisle - (16:29): IMO the version in the cert should only have to do with how the request is sent. EG: if the response will only be the cert and nothing else, the version in the cert is not incremented but the version given in the header (I can accept version...) is.  
cjdelisle - (16:30): If the request is sent in non-http, (like a udp packet or a specially crafted dns request) then the version number in the cert must be incremented.  
cjdelisle - (16:31): otherwise old versions will have no idea that they are being given a request in the format of a newer version.  
bblfish - (16:31): the problem is certs are served at the TLS layer  
bblfish - (16:31): so things work differently there  
bblfish - (16:31): it's below http  
bblfish - (16:32): so unless you want to re-engineer TLS...  
cjdelisle - (16:32): I'm talking about the request to the home site which holds the modulus (?)  
cjdelisle - (16:32): So foafssl-request-version goes in the cert and foafssl-response-version is sent in the header of the request.  
cjdelisle - (16:33): the numbers specify the highest version which the foafssl installation can handle.  
cjdelisle - (16:34): I guess a foafssl-response-version should be in the response as well, that way the requester knows what they are reading.  
bblfish - (16:34): ah  
bblfish - (16:34): for creating the key you can do what you want  
bblfish - (16:34): since you control the server  
bblfish - (16:34): it's a form. So you can pass any paramters you want  
bblfish - (16:35): but probably you just want to ask your user for a DN, and perhaps an expiry date  
cjdelisle - (16:35): The event I'm talking about is then somebody authenticates with website alice but he is a member of website bob. Alice must make a request to bob.  
cjdelisle - (16:36): and it's in everyone's favor to make that request go as quickly as possible.  
bblfish - (16:37): ah ok  
MartinCleaver\_ joined #xwiki at 16:37  
bblfish - (16:37): there you can do two things, you can check your cache  
bblfish - (16:37): first  
bblfish - (16:37): to see if he has already logged in  
bblfish - (16:38): then you can do a conditional GET request  
bblfish - (16:38): if you have something  
bblfish - (16:38): that may be out of date  
MartinCleaver left at 16:39 (Ping timeout: 276 seconds  
MartinCleaver\_ is now known as MartinCleaver ([[email protected]](https://dev.xwiki.org/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection)
